awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Learning from Near and Distant Others
awd_abstract_narration:
People constantly learn from those in their social worlds. Although these teachers are often close to their students (similar to themselves, living nearby, located in the same time period, etc.), they can also be far away: socially distant, spatially distant, and even temporally distant. This research tests the hypothesis that concrete knowledge is more easily learned from nearby teachers, while abstract knowledge is more readily learned from distant teachers. To accomplish this, the PIs will examine the role of proximity on the conceptualization of knowledge and on the effectiveness of different types of learning. The proposed research has practical implications for teaching in a wide variety of contexts; from parents teaching children, to schools looking to foster abstract thinking. A practical and policy implication of this work is that there may be types of knowledge (e.g., abstract concepts) in which students may actually learn better when an instructor is distant (e.g., distance learning or online courses). Overall, the societal benefits of the proposed research will provide clear guidance on future innovations in America's educational system.

This research is based on Construal Level Theory which posits that people's ability to conceptualize objects and events varies by the psychological proximity of this information. The researchers will investigate, in addition to proximity, whether the effectiveness of an instructor will also vary by the types knowledge gained: 1) concrete knowledge (i.e., "volunteering at the animal shelter"); or 2) abstract knowledge (i.e., "caring about the well-being of abandoned cats and dogs"). The researchers will examine the role of proximity (social, spatial, or temporal distance) and the level of abstraction of knowledge gained on two modes of instruction: 1) learning through imitation or modeling; and 2) learning transfer.  The results will contribute to a broader understanding of how people learn from those around them and how the effects of psychological distance on social learning depend on the nature of what is learned and how it is learned.

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this project was to explore the role of distance in learning. In prior work, we argued that interacting with a distant person leads people to adopt a more abstract approach in order to best connect with that distant person. In this project we continued to explore the role of abstraction in relationships that occur across distance, exploring specifically how distance shapes the way that we learn.

We focused on several different types of learning. For example, focusing on what we learn from other people, we showed that people's learning is influenced by the person from whom they learn. Specifically, we distinguished concrete, low-level knowledge from abstract, high-level knowledge, and found that people learn higher level information from more socially distant targets. We also explored similar effects when people learn via imitation: we found that people engaged in more literal imitation of a model's physical actions (imitating the model’s concrete, low-level actions, not only the more abstract goals of the model’s actions) when they imitated a near model rather than a distant model. Relatedly, we also looked at what people learn from stories. We found that when a story involves something more distal (the protagonist, for example, lived in a distant time or place) people generated broader lessons from the story than when the story context is more proximal.

We also conducted several studies exploring one important way that people learn: through use of analogies. We found that people mapped analogies more abstractly when they were forming an analogy between a stimulus and something they previously encountered (which was thereby distant) than when they were forming an analogy between a stimulus and something encountered concurrently. We also considered analogical transfer in solving problems as a function of the learning source: people were more likely to transfer lessons learned from a more distal learning source than a near one.  

In addition to our major focus on learning, we also continued our research on several projects more generally related to how abstraction facilitates relationships across distance. For example, we continued research on a project focusing on distance and relative deprivation, finding that when you compare what you have with what a distal target has, you focus relatively more on abstract features of comparison (compared to concrete features of comparison) than when you compare what you have with a near target. We also continued research on projects related to communication across distance. In one of these, we developed a computer-based method for understanding how abstractly people are communicating, developing a tool that we hope will help researchers in the future. We also explored gender differences in communicative abstraction (finding that women generally speak more concretely than men) and implications this has for women’s attainment of status, power, and entrepreneurship-related opportunities.

Our findings help to support and build theory, and also have a number of practical implications. They emphasize that critical cognitive outcomes such as learning can be broadly influenced by social psychological variables, such as the distance of a teacher, and thus point the way to potential interventions based on this work to enhance and support learning. More generally, our findings highlight the continued relevance of distance in a world where we increasingly move back-and-forth within our daily lives between interacting with those very close to us and those very far away.
